statement.para: There is a special collection of linear transformations, called invertible, whose effect on space can be reversed. Here is an example: A dilation D\from \RNr[n]\to \RNr[n] by the factor c > 1 magnifies distances by the factor c. The effect of such a dilation can be reversed by a contraction with factor 1/c.
The picture below illustrates this situation for D\from \RNr[2]\to \RNr[2] with magnification factor c=3/2. Accordingly the D-inverting contraction C has contraction factor 2/3.
